Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Spatiotemporal Evolution of Radio-induced Aurora at the University of Alaska Fairbanks (UAF) High-frequency Active Auroral Research Program (HAARP) Observatory
Award.AbstractNarration:
This RAPID would support ionosphere radio modification experiments at the Alaska High-frequency Active Auroral Research Program (HAARP) Observatory during its first university-run campaign, planned for February 2017. The application of the research specifically is to study with high temporal resolution the evolution of the white-light morphology of the artificial radio-induced aurora. Ownership of the HAARP facility was transferred from the US Air Force to the University of Alaska Fairbanks (UAF) in August, 2015. During campaigns, significant expenditures for fuel and personnel are required. Large start-up costs make HAARP experiments largely inaccessible to individual researchers unless multiple experiments and funding sources can be bundled together during a campaign of up to two-week duration. Based on recent pledged support from sponsors, UAF plans to conduct a limited experiment campaign in February 2017; this schedule is unflexible and consequently, the RAPID management of the award would enable the schedule to be enhanced with additional experiments thus utilizing the HAARP facility more effectively. Broader impacts will be maximized by encouraging public participation in various roles.

This project is a singular opportunity for researchers to conduct ionosphere modification experiments by taking advantage of efficiencies gained through bundling onto the campaign already planned for February. The primary experimental objective of this project is to measure time-dependent artificial airglow or "aurora" morphology with a sensitive white-light video camera capable of 30 frames per second temporal resolution. The secondary experimental objective is to test Arctic HF radio propagation paths using community and amateur radio (ham) participation. Both experiment objectives are highly relevant to active areas of space physics and Arctic radio communications research. Ionosphere radio modification is an important experimental technique for investigating: 1) plasma processes difficult or impossible to replicate in a laboratory, 2) the near-earth space environment, 3) radio propagation properties, and 4) natural processes such as aurora that transfer energy into the upper atmosphere. The primary and secondary objectives are 1) to measure the white-light artificial aurora morphology with high temporal resolution and 2) to test possible HF radio propagation paths in the Arctic. Both experiment objectives align with formerly active areas of research at HAARP prior to the suspension of operations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A low-cost imaging system for white-light measurements of artificial airglow emissions was acquired and deployed at HAARP. Operation of the imaging system was verified by successfully making observations of the dawn-side pulsating aurora, a phenomenon with low-intensity and rapid airglow emissions expected to be comparable to strong artificial airglow emissions at HAARP. One imaging system was deployed at HAARP for zenith and magnetic zenith observations of artificial airglow over the facility and a second system was deployed at Poker Flat Research Range for side-view observations.

Experiments were performed at the HAARP facility during the February 2017, September 2017, and July-August 2018 campaigns. Artificial airglow was successfully generated and detected with collaborator instrumentation during the September 2017 campaign in a novel experiment that simultaneously broadcast the first Slow Scan Television (SSTV) image to citizen scientist volunteers in the United States and Canada. A novel HF propagation experiment was successfully conducted using the Weak Signal Propagation Reporter (WSPR) network during the July-August 2018 campaign.

The specific primary objective was to test two scientific hypotheses regarding the dependence of HF-enhanced airglow intensity on the selection of radio wave frequency and polarization. The specific secondary objective was to demonstrate measurements of global HF propagation using novel crowd-sourced citizen-science techniques. Opportunities for incorporating activities facilitating unique broader impacts were to be explored. Exceptional ionosphere conditions prevented collecting enough data to reach a conclusion regarding the proposed scientific hypotheses but nevertheless several important results were obtained.

The first result was a demonstration that an O-mode pump wave amplitude modulated with Slow Scan Television (SSTV) images can still generate artificial airglow. These images were received and decoded by citizen scientists in the United States and Canada. This was the first ever simultaneous artificial aurora created by the transmission of SSTV images.

The second result demonstrated a proof of concept with high potential intellectual merit that also had significant broader impacts. During the WSPR experiment for measuring HF propagation for several beam configurations, 300 measurements were recorded from 100 stations located throughout the United States and Canada. These stations were operated by amateur (ham) radio operators, shortwave radio enthusiasts, and citizen scientists. HF radio propagation is still a hard problem. Current HF propagation models are still largely based on codes from the 1970s are insufficient for reliable real-time HF propagation prediction. The technique developed during this project used a powerful and flexible HF radio transmitter combined with a large-scale distributed network of internet-connected receivers maintained by citizen scientists. Consequently, this technique demonstrates a new capability for gathering real-time data that can be used in future physics-based and assimilative models of HF-radio propagation.

The key outcomes of this project include:

  1. Acquisition, testing, and deployment of a second white-light video imager for recording natural and artificial airglow emissions
  2. The first successful creation and detection of artificial airglow simultaneous with a beam modulation carrying an SSTV transmission decoded by citizen scientists in the United States and Canada
  3. The first use of an ionosphere radio modification facility to make large-scale measurements of HF radio propagation using a large distributed network of receivers maintained by ham radio operators, shortwave radio listeners, and citizen scientists
